results.title: Kiss me Petruchio
results.creator_credit: New York Shakespeare Festival, Joseph Papp, Wilford Leach and Christopher Dixon
results.brief_description: An amusing, fast-paced documentary based on the New York Shakespeare Festival’s production of “The Taming of the Shrew” starring Meryl Streep and Raul Julia. The film goes behind the scenes to find out what makes the 400-year-old play relevant to audiences today. Combines excerpts from the performance, with comments by the leading actors and members of the audience.

results.title: Kiss me deadly
results.brief_description: A chance encounter leading to, what is referred to in the film as, the search for ‘the great whatsit’, follows the conventional investigative structure of the private eye film. However, the bravura visual style, the array of characterisation and the aural fabric of allusion and metaphor add meaning to this basic structure, marking the film as the climax of the initial noir cycle. The private eye, Mike Hammer, is portrayed as a fascistic anti-hero ultimately caught between big crime and big government. Aldrich and Bezzerides consciously denounce Spillane’s sleazy creation injecting in its place an atmosphere of cold war hysteria, an implicit critique of the ‘end justifies the means’ mentality.

results.title: Kismet
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Arthur Freed and Vincente Minnelli
results.brief_description: Kismet is an enchanting musical filled with sensual dance and magical song. Howard Keel plays the witty poet-beggar whose quick tongue is forever getting him in trouble…and out again. Masquerading as Hajj, a famous sorcerer with magic powers, he has just the right amount of charm to turn a fair lady’s head, a fair lady who happens to be the Wazir’s Number One Wife! Cast also includes Ann Blyth, Dolores Grey, Vic Damone.

results.title: Kiribati? Here we are
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Don Murray and John Shaw
results.brief_description: On 12 July 1979 the Gilbert Islands, in the Central Pacific Ocean, became independent from British rule. The film shows the way of life of the people and includes a brief historical background.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Australia, Don Murray and John Shaw

results.title: Kiri Te Kanawa at Christmas
results.brief_description: A magical live performance from the Barbican Hall in London with Dame Kiri Te Kanawa singing her favourite Christmas songs. They include “Let the Bright Seraphim”, “Angels from the Realms of Glory” and “Silver Bells”. Dame Kiri is accompanied by the Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Carl Davis, and the Tallis Chamber Choir.

results.title: Kiri Te Kanawa
results.brief_description: Accompanied by well-known pianist Richard Amner, Dame Kiri offers a selection of pieces from various composers, including Schubert’s “Gretchen Am Spinnrade”, Strauss’ “Muttertandelei” and three delightful pieces from Walton with poems by Dame Edith Sitwell “Through Golden Trellises”, “Daphne” and “Old Sir Faulk”.

results.title: Kipling's India
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission, Alan Bateman and Lloyd Capps
results.brief_description: 19th century author, Rudyard Kipling spent the first six years of his life in Bombay where his father taught sculpture. After schooling in Britain, he returned to India to work for seven years as a journalist before returning forever to England to write full time. Although he never returned to India, Kipling never lost his delight in the romance, mystery and endless variety of Indian life. India formed his imagination and provided his best themes. In this program, Keith Adam retraces the journey of Kipling’s character Kim, to locate traces of the old India Kipling loved, and in doing so exposes us to the fascination of India.

results.title: Kings row
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, William Cameron Menzies and Sam Wood
results.brief_description: Kings Row was well ahead of its time, anticipating fifties melodramas such as “Peyton Place” and those of Sirk, Minnelli et al., in its subversive view of small town America. The scriptwriter Casey Robinson takes most of the credit for managing to win the approval of Production Code officials during the repressive Breen and post-Breen years. Incest in the novel is thinly disguised in the film as hereditary insanity. Leg amputation is virtually synonymous with castration. The American doctor-fathers are middle class monsters while positive values are inverted almost exclusively in European immigrants and the working class. Religion rates no mention in a world clearly polarised between good and evil. The young people’s struggle to overcome obstacles is heightened to the point of self parody as melodrama of triumph. Visual design was mainly the work of William Cameron Menzies (who storyboarded the whole film) and cinematographer James Wong Howe. From the novel by Henry Bellamann. Cast includes: Ann Sheridan, Robert Cummings, Ronald Reagan, Betty Field, Charles Coburn.

results.title: Kings of sport
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional and Arthur C. Stevens
results.brief_description: Introducing twenty five years of sporting champions, including; Henry Seagrove on land and water; Donald Campbell’s land speed record; John Cobb; TT Races on the Isle of Man; Fred Perry at Wimbledon; Henry Cotton the golfer; Denis Compton and Donald Bradman at cricket.

results.title: Kings' horses
results.creator_credit: Athos Film Productions, Peter Bucknall and Gerald Weinbien
results.brief_description: An historical documentary on the relationship between humans and horses. From the first domestication in pre-historic Asia to the present day.
